hints_latex: Sketch a diagram of the situation.
hints_raw: Sketch a diagram of the situation.
question: 2 (a)
sols_html:
We see the function and a sketch of the volume in the following figure.

We use the shell method

\[\begin{aligned} V = 2\pi\int h(z)z \,dz\end{aligned}\]

to find the volume. Therefore we need to determine what is the height \(h(z)\) and what is the integral variable \(z\).

On the next figure we see, that the height is the inverse of the function

\[\begin{aligned} y=f(x) = 1-x^2.\end{aligned}\]

And for this height the integral variable \(z\) is the distance from \(y\) to the rotating axis, which is \(y=-2.\)

So, we find z = y + 2 and for the height we calculate

\[\begin{aligned} f(x)=y=1-x^2\end{aligned}\]

\[\begin{aligned} x^2=1-y\end{aligned}\]

\[\begin{aligned} f^{-1}(y)=x=\sqrt{1-y}.\end{aligned}\]

For convenience, we calculate half of the volume and drop the left half. Then we can take

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle h(z)=\sqrt{1-y}\end{aligned}\]

for z = y + 2.

The boundaries of the integral must be the left and right edge of the interval for \(y=[0,1]\). Now we need to calculate the integral

\[\begin{aligned} \frac12 V &= 2\pi\int h(z)z\,dz\\ &= 2\pi\int_0^1 (y+2)\sqrt{1-y}\,dy\\ &= 2\pi\overbrace{\int_0^1\underbrace{y}_{=u}\underbrace{\sqrt{1-y}}_{=dv}\,dy}^{\text{use integration by parts}} + 2\pi\int_0^12\sqrt{1-y}\,dy\\ &= 2\pi\left[y(1-y)^{\frac32}(-\frac23)\right]_0^1 + 2\pi\frac23\int_0^1 (1-y)^{\frac32}\,dy + 2\pi2\left[(1-y)^{\frac32}\right]_0^1\\ &= 0 + 2\pi\frac23\left[(1-y)^{\frac52}(-\frac25)\right]^1_0 - 0 + 2\pi\frac43\\ &= 2\pi\frac{4}{15} + 2\pi\frac43\\ &= \frac{16\pi}{5}\end{aligned}\]

So, we get for the volume

\[\begin{aligned} V= \frac{32\pi}{5}.\end{aligned}\]

We see the function and a sketch of the volume in the following figure.

We use the washers method

\[\begin{aligned} V = \pi\int (R_O(x)^2 - R_I(x)^2) \,dx\end{aligned}\]

to find the volume, where RO is the outer radius of the washer and RI is inner radius. From the diagram above, we see that \(R_O(x) = 1 - x^2 + 2 = 3 - x^2\), and \(R_I(x) = 2\).

We are integrating along x, so the boundaries of the integral must be \(x=[-1,1]\). Now we need to calculate the integral

\[\begin{aligned} V &= \pi\int (R_O(x)^2 - R_I(x)^2) \,dx \\ &= \pi\int_{-1}^1 ((3 - x^2)^2 - 4) \,dx\\ &= \pi\int_{-1}^1 (9 - 6x^2 + x^4 - 4) \,dx\\ &= \pi\int_{-1}^1 (5 - 6x^2 + x^4) \,dx\\ &= \pi\left[5x - 2x^3 + \frac{1}{5}x^5\right]_{-1}^1\\ &= \pi\left[\left(5 - 2 + \frac{1}{5}\right) - \left(5(-1) - 2(-1)^3 + \frac{1}{5}(-1)^5\right)\right]\\ &= \pi\left(10 - 4 + \frac{2}{5}\right)\\ &= \frac{32\pi}{5}\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
We see the function and a sketch of the volume in the following figure.

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH101/April_2010/Math_Exam_Resources_Courses_MATH101_April_2010_Question_2_(a)_picture.jpg}

We use the washers method

\begin{align*}
V = \pi\int (R_O(x)^2 - R_I(x)^2) \,dx
\end{align*} to find the volume, where
R\textsubscript{O} is the outer radius of the washer and
R\textsubscript{I} is inner radius. From the diagram above, we see that
$R_O(x) = 1 - x^2 + 2 = 3 - x^2$, and $R_I(x) = 2$.

We are integrating along \emph{x}, so the boundaries of the integral
must be $x=[-1,1]$. Now we need to calculate the integral

\begin{align*}
V &= \pi\int (R_O(x)^2 - R_I(x)^2) \,dx  \\
&= \pi\int_{-1}^1 ((3 - x^2)^2 - 4) \,dx\\
&= \pi\int_{-1}^1 (9 - 6x^2 + x^4 - 4) \,dx\\
&= \pi\int_{-1}^1 (5 - 6x^2 + x^4) \,dx\\
&= \pi\left[5x - 2x^3 + \frac{1}{5}x^5\right]_{-1}^1\\
&= \pi\left[\left(5 - 2 + \frac{1}{5}\right) - \left(5(-1) - 2(-1)^3 + \frac{1}{5}(-1)^5\right)\right]\\
&= \pi\left(10 - 4 + \frac{2}{5}\right)\\
&= \frac{32\pi}{5}
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
We see the function and a sketch of the volume in the following figure.

[[File:Math_Exam_Resources_Courses_MATH101_April_2010_Question_2_(a)_picture.jpg|250px]]

We use the shell method
:<math>
V = 2\pi\int h(z)z \,dz </math>
to find the volume. Therefore we need to determine what is the height <math>h(z) </math> and what is the integral variable <math>z </math>.

On the next figure we see, that the height is the inverse of the function
:<math>
y=f(x) = 1-x^2.
</math>
And for this height the integral variable <math>z </math> is the distance from <math>y </math> to the rotating axis, which is <math>y=-2. </math>

[[File:Math_Exam_Resources_Courses_MATH101_April_2010_Question_2_(a)_picture_2.jpg|250px]]

So, we find ''z'' = ''y'' + 2 and for the height we calculate

:<math>f(x)=y=1-x^2\ </math>

:<math>x^2=1-y\ </math>

:<math>f^{-1}(y)=x=\sqrt{1-y}.\ </math>

For convenience, we calculate half of the volume and drop the left half. Then we can take
:<math>\displaystyle
h(z)=\sqrt{1-y}</math>
for ''z'' = ''y'' + 2.

The boundaries of the integral must be the left and right edge of the interval for <math> y=[0,1] </math>. Now we need to calculate the integral

:<math>\begin{align}
\frac12 V &=  2\pi\int h(z)z\,dz\\
&=  2\pi\int_0^1 (y+2)\sqrt{1-y}\,dy\\
&= 2\pi\overbrace{\int_0^1\underbrace{y}_{=u}\underbrace{\sqrt{1-y}}_{=dv}\,dy}^{\text{use integration by parts}} + 2\pi\int_0^12\sqrt{1-y}\,dy\\
&= 2\pi\left[y(1-y)^{\frac32}(-\frac23)\right]_0^1 + 2\pi\frac23\int_0^1 (1-y)^{\frac32}\,dy + 2\pi2\left[(1-y)^{\frac32}\right]_0^1\\
&= 0 + 2\pi\frac23\left[(1-y)^{\frac52}(-\frac25)\right]^1_0 - 0 + 2\pi\frac43\\
&= 2\pi\frac{4}{15} + 2\pi\frac43\\
&= \frac{16\pi}{5}
\end{align}</math>

So, we get for the volume

:<math>V= \frac{32\pi}{5}.</math>
We see the function and a sketch of the volume in the following figure.

[[File:Math_Exam_Resources_Courses_MATH101_April_2010_Question_2_(a)_picture.jpg|250px]]

We use the washers method
:<math>
V = \pi\int (R_O(x)^2 - R_I(x)^2) \,dx </math>
to find the volume, where R<sub>O</sub> is the outer radius of the washer and R<sub>I</sub> is inner radius. From the diagram above, we see that <math> R_O(x) = 1 - x^2 + 2 = 3 - x^2</math>, and <math>R_I(x) = 2</math>.

We are integrating along ''x'', so the boundaries of the integral must be <math> x=[-1,1] </math>. Now we need to calculate the integral
:<math>\begin{align}
V &= \pi\int (R_O(x)^2 - R_I(x)^2) \,dx  \\
&= \pi\int_{-1}^1 ((3 - x^2)^2 - 4) \,dx\\
&= \pi\int_{-1}^1 (9 - 6x^2 + x^4 - 4) \,dx\\
&= \pi\int_{-1}^1 (5 - 6x^2 + x^4) \,dx\\
&= \pi\left[5x - 2x^3 + \frac{1}{5}x^5\right]_{-1}^1\\
&= \pi\left[\left(5 - 2 + \frac{1}{5}\right) - \left(5(-1) - 2(-1)^3 + \frac{1}{5}(-1)^5\right)\right]\\
&= \pi\left(10 - 4 + \frac{2}{5}\right)\\
&= \frac{32\pi}{5}
\end{align}</math>
statement_html:
Full-Solution Problem. Justify your answer and show all your work. Simplification of the answer is not required.

The bounded region that lies between the \(x\)-axis and the curve \(y=1-x^2\) is revolved about the line \(y=-2.\) Find the volume of the resulting solid of revolution.
statement_latex:

resulting solid of revolution.
